Based on the search results, here's what I found about Firecrawl API's actions parameter for clicking and expanding JavaScript content:

## Firecrawl Actions Parameter

Firecrawl supports actions including click, scroll, input, wait and more before extracting data.

### How Actions Work

Firecrawl supports dynamic scraping by default. In the parameters of scrape() or batch_scrape(), you can define necessary actions to reach the target state of the page you are scraping.(no content)Firecrawl's actions feature handles interaction patterns programmatically. You can define a sequence of actions in your scrape request: scroll to the bottom of the page, click a "Load More" button, wait for new content to render, then extract all data.

### Example Usage

Here is an example of how to use actions to navigate to google.com, search for Firecrawl, click on the first result, and take a screenshot. It is important to almost always use the wait action before/after executing other actions to give enough time for the page to load.

Here's a code example from the documentation:

```python
from firecrawl import Firecrawl
firecrawl = Firecrawl(api_key="fc-YOUR-API-KEY")

doc = firecrawl.scrape(
    url="https://example.com/login",
    formats=["markdown"],
    actions=[
        {"type": "write", "text": "[email protected]"},
        {"type": "press", "key": "Tab"},
        {"type": "write", "text": "secret"},
        {"type": "click", "selector": 'button[type="submit"]'},
        {"type": "wait", "milliseconds": 1500},
        {"type": "screenshot", "fullPage": True},
    ],
)
```

### Timing Considerations

The wait action is crucialâ€”it gives the page time to fetch and render new content after each interaction.(no content)Firecrawl handles timing automatically for standard scenarios, monitoring network activity and DOM changes to determine when pages are ready. For custom interactions using actions, explicit wait commands give you control over timing between steps.

### Use Cases

Each pattern requires specific actions: scrolling to trigger lazy loading, clicking buttons to expand content, filling form fields to submit queries, or navigating through tabs to access different sections.

For more details, you can refer to the [Firecrawl documentation](https://docs.firecrawl.dev/advanced-scraping-guide#actions-actions).

## Keyboard Shortcuts (for Notion app/editor)

"Press cmd/ctrl + option/alt + T to expand or close all toggles in a toggle list."(no content)This shortcut expands all toggle blocks on the page, not just the selected ones. You can use the same CMD/CTRL + OPT/ALT + T shortcut to close all toggles simultaneously.

## Alternative Methods

One easy way to open all toggles in Notion is by highlighting all the toggle blocks on the page. Simply press "Ctrl/Cmd + A" on your keyboard. Once all the toggle blocks are highlighted, click one of the toggle triangles on the page. You should now see all the toggle blocks expand.

content.text:
Looks like there's no URL parameter for this. The methods mentioned are all keyboard shortcuts (`Cmd/Ctrl + Alt + T`) that only work in the interactive Notion app.

You'll need to add actions to your firecrawl proxy. Based on the Notion DOM, the selector for toggle blocks is typically something like:

```javascript
actions: [
    { type: "click", selector: "[aria-label='Toggle']" },  // or similar
    { type: "wait", milliseconds: 500 }
]
```

You may need to inspect the actual Notion page to find the right selector, since Notion's class names are often obfuscated/dynamic.

Sources:
- [How to Open All Toggles in Notion + Keyboard Shortcut](https://super.so/blog/how-to-open-all-toggles-in-notion-keyboard-shortcut)

## Program Requirements and Key Dates

Jan 5 - March 28: Research Phase (12 weeks)

Jan 5: Orientation Day

Jan 7: Alumni Lightning Talks

Jan 9: Kick-off Mixer with wider Bay Area AIS community: [RSVP](https://luma.com/ayrz6pxc)

Jan 9: Housing and office agreements due to Nate

Feb 6: Milestone #1 Research project description is due

TBD: Career Fair

March (TBD): Symposium abstract/slides due

March 28: Milestone #2 Fellow Symposium presentations and poster session

March 29 by 2 PM: Check out of MATS-provided accommodations (unless specifically told otherwise)

April 11: Extension Phase begins (for select fellows)

![](https://matsprogram.notion.site/image/attachment%3A351031c9-064d-4f85-aef8-dadb8b928844%3AScreenshot_2025-12-15_at_2.23.20_PM.png?table=block&id=2dfa0e14-b0ad-802f-9fac-de21b926c958&spaceId=0d3e27ad-4523-4665-9d59-8502d77dc404&width=2000&userId=&cache=v2)

## Financial Support

MATS itself cannot provide any funding; however, [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) has generously offered to provide a grant totaling $15k for completing the Research Phase. This will be disbursed in two parts: half at the beginning and half at the end of the main MATS program. The second half of the grant is prorated based on the number of weeks fellows participate in the program.

MATS participants may have to pay taxes on their grants based on the rules of the countries where they are a resident for tax purposes. The grants should be regarded as "private grants from a non-profit entity (i.e., [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not MATS) provided to individuals for independent research and participation in a US-based seminar program." While fellow grants are provided by [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not [Effective Ventures](https://ev.org/), fellows may find [this tax advice](https://funds.effectivealtruism.org/help/1lZgor0q3CImJwTt0xefPR) helpful.

## Training Materials

### Mentor Curriculum

Some mentors have developed a training curriculum for their fellows. Fellows are expected to carefully read through their mentorâ€™s assigned curriculum and explore any disagreements or confusion in their weekly mentor meetings. If you have already thoroughly read any mentor curriculum elements prior to the start of the program, or find that you are progressing faster than expected, please reach out to your mentor for more advanced reading material.

## Research Phase Overview (Jan 5 - March 28)

### Commitment

The default time frame for this program phase is 40hrs/week during Jan 5 - March 28, but these dates are flexible. For example, some fellows may choose to do part-time for some weeks to accommodate school commitments. Please contact a member of the MATS team or email exec@matsprogram.org if you would like alternative program dates or weekly commitments.

By default, we expect fellows to complete this program in-person in our Berkeley, California offices, with some exceptions of fellows who will complete the program from London, UK. Accommodation will also be provided in Berkeley; housing will be co-located with the office for convenience. We will also try to tailor accommodations to your preferences, e.g., for greater work-home separation. Please contact a member of the MATS team or email kali@matsprogram.org if you require any support.

### Milestones

#### \#1: Research project description (due Feb 6)

The ~2 page project description consists of a description of your proposed research project during the MATS program and a justification of why you chose this project in consultation with your mentor. The RP is intended to encourage fellows to critically evaluate their projectâ€™s theory of change and provide the MATS team and MATS grant manager with data on the program.

More information will be released about the project description in the coming weeks.

#### \#2: Fellow Symposium (March 28)

The Research Phase concludes with a full-day Symposium, during which all fellows present posters about their research project and some teams deliver 10-minute talks to their peers and members of the Berkeley AI safety community.

You can find more information about the assignment, along with the rubric and and submission form on the Symposium section of the Fellow Handbook.

### Research Projects

During the research phase of the program, mentors will meet with fellows for around 1-2 h/week to share their research agenda and supervise the fellowsâ€™ research projects. Fellows' research directions may initially be chosen by the mentors, but by default, fellows are expected to develop their independent research direction as the program continues.

### Posting on LessWrong

Use [shortform](https://www.lesswrong.com/shortform) for fast, unfiltered ideas you want to share;

Seek feedback on drafts in the [#feedback-on-posts-or-drafts](https://serialignment-qo78019.slack.com/archives/C03NFC8D5PS) Slack channel if you want help improving technical aspects, clarity, or conciseness;

Ask your mentor if they are interested in providing feedback on drafts.

Please add the [â€œMATS programâ€ tag](https://www.lesswrong.com/tag/mats-program) and a disclaimer, â€œProduced as part of the [MATS Program](https://www.matsprogram.org/) \- Winter 2026 Cohortâ€ to all posts that were produced as part of the MATS program so that:

The MATS team can monitor fellow output;

Our grant managers and ecosystem partners can assess MATS' output.

There is no need to add disclaimers for shortform posts.

### Housing and Offices

We have acquired office space and housing for fellows in Berkeley, California from Jan 4 to March 29. We also offer the possibility to be remote or work from our London office, although this is not encouraged and may compromise the program's quality. Please contact Kali at kali@matsprogram.org if you have concerns regarding agreed-upon housing arrangements or if you have any questions. See the Housing section and the Office section in the Fellow Handbook for more information.

### Seminar Program

Educational seminars and workshops will be held 2-4 times per week. See the [Events Calendar](https://scholar-handbook.super.site/events-calendar) for details, and you can find recordings [here](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/gbxkv6pm7fs30sduuc773/AC9CC81V0ZS_k2-Phl7yEz4?rlkey=mm3lck9esae3sxsaoffxh5wgy&st=xsvqz5b0&dl=0).

## Extension Phase Overview

### Purpose

The Extension Phase is aimed at supporting fellows to pursue their research projects with increasing autonomy from their mentors and the structure that MATS provided in the Research Phase. During the Extension, we expect that fellows formalize their research projects into what are usually their first publications, and begin to compare potential next steps and future directions. To support them in this, we continue to offer day-to-day productivity support (e.g., daily stand-ups, Research Management debugging, 1:1 career coaching), and we put on a mixture of seminars, workshops, and networking events, especially for the fellows based in the London office.

This is all with the aim of preparing fellows to transition out of the supportive environment of the MATS program, by frequently reminding them to further develop their longer term plans, and to make new connections that help them advance those plans. All the while, we expect that fellows receive continued support from their mentors, albeit in most cases with decreasing frequency.

### Location

By default, the Extension takes place at the MATS office in London. You will have access to MATS support staff, an office space, and other resources. There is no guarantee that there will be sufficient office space available to you in Berkeley as the MATS office will close down once the program is complete.

### Application Process

In the middle of the Research Phase, fellows will have the opportunity to meet with their mentor and request that they submit a recommendation for an Extension to the MATS team. This recommendation is essentially an endorsement by the mentor for you to continue your research project under their supervision for an additional 6-12 month period. The mentor reference and the fellow research project description will be the two primary factors in Extension Phase decisions.

MATS will be able to offer funding to Extension Phase fellows, without them needing to apply for external funding. This funding would cover a stipend for the fellow, any needed compute resources, and any needed office space. If MATS does not have enough funds available to support a fellow during the extension phase, we encourage them to explore external funding options if the fellow and their mentor are interested in pursuing the extensionâ€“while not guaranteed, it is possible that MATS may be able to support fellows that secure external funding. Possible external funder include [Open Philanthropy](https://www.openphilanthropy.org/) or the [Long Term Future Fund](https://funds.effectivealtruism.org/funds/far-future) (LTFF). The year-round [Career Development and Transition Funding (CDTF)](https://www.openphilanthropy.org/career-development-and-transition-funding/) program supports individuals pursuing or transitioning into research aimed at reducing global catastrophic risks. [Manifund Regrants](https://manifund.org/), is a platform where AI Safety experts allocate funds quickly and flexibly. Additional options typically open applications only once or twice a year. These include [Cooperative AI Foundation (CAIF)](https://www.cooperativeai.com/), the [AI Safety Fund (AISF)](https://www.aisafetyfund.org/), the [CLR Fund](https://longtermrisk.org/grantmaking/) and the [AI Risk Mitigation Fund](https://www.airiskfund.com/). MATS is available to help fellows navigate these funding processes if they choose to apply to any of these. MATS is additionally happy to help alumni find a position at an established alignment research organization or acquire funding from other sources.

### Personal guests

You are welcome to bring guests to the office at Lighthaven. By and large we trust you to make reasonable choices and exercise good judgment with the visitors you host. When hosting a visitor, you are responsible for your visitorâ€™s behavior, and, like with all our policies, please aspire to follow the spirit of the policy, and not just the letter of the law. ### AIS community guests or acquaintances

For guests that are not your personal guests, please direct them to theÂ [Expression of Interest Form](https://airtable.com/appZq2f1sM0tW9kH7/pagvVP821ZgDug1nI/form)Â to receive approval from the MATS team. A guestÂ mustÂ receive email approval to enter the Office. Until they receive approval, they are not invited to the office. A guest must fill out the form for each independent visit.

The form should be filled out again for each subsequent visit request not covered by previous entries of the EOI form (e.g., if they just wanted to visit for occasional meetings previously, but now want a hotdesk).

## Slack Channels

MATS Slack norms are:

Reply to a specific message in a thread, not to the whole channel. This is to keep conversations in one place and not overwhelm channels.

Everything that applies to the MATS office space per the CHP applies to the MATS Slack as well, e.g. no harassment, romantic advances, etc.

Your stream-\[mentor name\]-9 channel is meant to be the main communication channel for you, all other fellows working with your mentor, and your mentor. It is a great place to ask questions, as the MATS team can jump in as necessary.

The announcements-9 channel will be where the MATS team will post important reminders and tips. Turn notifications on for this channel.

The cohort-9 channel is a place for fellows, mentors, and MATS team members to post program and research project-relevant questions and announcements. We encourage you to e.g. start your own discussion groups and ask any clarifying questions that may unblock you and other fellows.

The social-events-9 channel is where we welcome anyone to organize their own events, and random-9 is for anything else.

All people in the MATS Slack are added to the channels #general and #introductions. But, there are more channels in the MATS slack that most fellows are part of.

You can join open channels by clicking on â€œAdd channelsâ€ and then â€œbrowse channels.â€ Then, click â€œjoinâ€ on the channels that you would like to be part of. Here are additional channels that are commonly used and descriptions of the content in those channels:

#appreciation - To share gratefulness

#climbing - To coordinate plans for climbing, e.g., after work.

#opportunities - Opportunities for funding, jobs, fellowships, research collaborations, etc.

#photos - To share pictures you take

#random - To ask questions, share thoughts, and send messages when you arenâ€™t sure what channel they belong in.

#study - There are a couple of study group channels. These channels start with #study (eg: #study-mech-interp).

#technical\_questions - Need help debugging? Post here!

#whiteboards - To upload photos of public whiteboards before you erase them.

Contact Nate if youâ€™re feeling poorly (or any Community Manager secondarily). They can help you find resources such as food and supply delivery. For any questions about this policy, contact a Community Manager, not another member of the MATS team.

![ðŸ¤ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

When we share space with other programs, we will need to adhere to illness policies that are agreed upon by both parties.

We recommend staying up to date on COVID and flu vaccines and getting a vaccine prior to arriving to MATS (travel insurance will often not cover this) or [scheduling a COVID and flu vaccine appointment at CVS](https://www.cvs.com/immunizations/get-vaccinated) (2655 Telegraph Ave, Berkeley), just a block away from Lighthaven. Getting vaccinated has high expected value for most fellows: even if the vaccine sets you back for a day, itâ€™s worth it to prevent a more serious illness later in the program that could consume many productive days right before a big deadline. When you get vaccinated, you are protecting the whole MATS community against a potential outbreak.

## If you have any symptomsâ€¦
--
### Compute

Please donâ€™t spend your own money on compute without first having a compute request approved. Please see our compute section for information on our new processes!

## Security

## Fellow requirements

The following security steps are mandatory for all fellows:

If you use your compute budget, you must secure any associated accounts with 2FA. We recommend authenticator apps, passkeys, and other non-text message or SMS based methods to be used as a second factor. This includes your personal email if it is used for logging into any systems that MATS provides to you.

Do not plug in any devices of unknown origin to your computer

Use a password manager for any credentials that cannot be tied to your email account. Password managers like BitWarden, 1Password, and others are generally a great starting place if you do not already have one. Install and use it to generate your password.

Do not reuse passwords between sites.

Do not share passwords with anyone.

If you need to walk away from your laptop, lock it.

If you think there are signs that any account compromise occurs, you must report it immediately using the #support-security Slack channel or to Ryan.

Everything below in this page is a recommendation.

## Email security

Phishing is a malicious attempt to steal sensitive information such as usernames, passwords, and credit card details by impersonating trustworthy entities. To avoid falling victim to phishing attacks, always be cautious of unsolicited emails or messages that ask for personal information or urge you to click on links or open attachments. Look for signs of phishing, such as spelling errors, unusual sender addresses, or a sense of urgency. Verify any suspicious communication directly with the organization or person it claims to be from, using secondary communication channels.

If you donâ€™t already have one active, please set up a Gmail account. This is a very good identity and email provider that comes with a lot of extra security features other emails will not have, and the default settings are generally much better for security than most other providers.

Avoid clicking on links from emails and instead visit websites from Google. While Google does have some protections for protecting you from malware in attachments they may miss things (including their own sponsored pages).

Check file extensions carefully. Be wary of:

Executable files (.exe, .bat, .cmd, .msi, .js);

Double extensions (document.pdf.exe);

Uncommon file types (.iso, .rar, .7z).

## Removable media

This includes USBs, SD cards and CDs and anything else you can stick in a computer or phone. These can carry malware and logging software. We know of examples where malicious actors give people computer mice or drop USBs around conferences so people will use these. The malware on these is often sophisticated and can get around native antivirus software so do not plug in any devices to your computer of unknown origin. For sharing media we recommend using cloud first channels like Google drive or email.

## Passwords and authentication

In general we recommend you always use the â€œLogin with Googleâ€ option where possible. This has many security checks and controls going on that protect your account credentials. If there is no option to do this and you must create a password in the application, we request that youÂ  install the Bitwarden Chrome add-on to store and generate the password. Additionally, when possible turn on multi-factor authentication within the app. This will mean it will require more than a password to sign you in and makes it much harder for people to guess your password. With multi-factor authentication, SMS or text-based authentication is now known to be extremely vulnerable to man in the middle attacks ( [example](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wVyu7NB7W6Y)). We recommend setting up one time codes with Google authenticator, Yubikeys, or using passkeys (biometrics that log you into your device).

One extremely common attack vector is spamming people with requests for multi-factor authentication once they have guessed your password. Often victims will get so fed up with the requests they will accept the multi-factor authentication prompt so be very wary of this and change your password to something more complex if this happens to you.

### Password complexity

The passwords generated by Bitwarden will all be secure; please avoid making them yourself. If you will make a password yourself, aim for a passphrase, multiple words in one password, the longer this is the harder it is to crack. Adding symbols to come of the words, like @ rather than a will significantly increase the complexity of guessing it. Do not share passwords between sites, this increases the risk of compromise greatly and it may be hard to remember which sites you shared it to in the event of compromise.

### Google accounts

Click on the Google icon of your Chrome browser in the top right and choose manage your Google account.

Click Security and follow all the security recommendations for your account.

## Physical security

Do not leave any documents lying around your desk or workspace, and wipe down whiteboards when you are done with them. If you need to walk away from your laptop, always lock it. This can be done virtually and physically. Some physical laptop locks exist so you can chain them to something nearby until you return. Also, be aware of anyone looking over your shoulder at your screen or listening to your calls in public spaces. If possible try to work with your back against a wall.

If you have lost your device or suspect it has been stolen please contact the MATS team immediately so they can clear accounts that have your compute funding allocation associated with them.

## Mobile device security

This includes phones and laptops. Beware what apps you download onto your device. Native antiviruses can miss some advanced malware so be careful and when worried run regular full antivirus scans. If you want a higher level of malware and device protection or will be working with highly sensitive information contact the MATS team for better protection options.

### Device manufacturer

If you will be using your phone for storing or accessing work data, avoid device manufacturers from China. These include OnePlus, Huawei, Xiaomi and Lenovo. With these companies there is no clear line between the phone company having your data and the [Chinese government having your data](https://theweek.com/articles/748176/chinese-smartphone-spying).

### Updated device

Ensuring your device receives regular OS updates and patches removes a lot of known security risks from older operating systems being exploited. So ensure your device is new enough that it is still protected by latest updates and you have not paused these updates.

### Additional security

iVerify is a privacy-preserving mobile device security platform, and we can provide you with licenses if you would like access to the leading mobile antivirus. If you use an iVerify license, please keep in mind that neither MATS nor their partnersÂ  will be able to see any data on your device, only device statistics like Operating system and the name of the device.

## Public Wi-Fi

We recommend not signing in to your major financial services on public wifi, and especially making sure that any site you visit has HTTPS in the URL (or that Chrome has the nice padlock icon).

With unsecured wifi networks people can listen in on the data transferred and there are many different layers of wifi security. Most public wifi networks you will find will have old and easily breakable wifi security practices. Mobile data is a much safer alternative. If you must use unsecured wifi networks we suggest using a VPN to protect you. We recommend MullVAD and NordVPN as an easy start.

## Information sharing

These threats include people talking to you or messaging you in order to gain information. These could include emails, or text messages posing as an authority or someone you know to ask you for information. Only contact others through previously established channels like email or Signal. Do not discuss any work related information on other messaging apps because they are probably not end to end encrypted and the app engineers can see/ use that information. Always verify the identity of anyone reaching out to you through unusual channels and only communicate through trustworthy channels. If necessary you may want a formal non-disclosure agreement depending on the type of information you will be sharing. Reach out to the MATS team for assistance on this.

## Reporting incidents

You will not be in trouble for reporting incidents. It helps MATS keep the organization secure and we want to encourage everyone to come forward with any questions and even false alarms. It is always better to overreport than underreport. Please report things to us via the #support-security channel on Slack! Donâ€™t be afraid to post messages like â€œ![âš ï¸](<Base64-Image-Removed>) URGENT MY DEVICE JUST GOT STOLENâ€ and tag people in the channel to get immediate assistance.

## International Travel

![âš ï¸ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

This is for your personal reference. Do not print this page. If you need a formal document to present to immigration officials, refer to the invitation letter you received over email.

## Key Takeaways

![âŒ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

You will not be working in the US. You are entering the United States to engage in independent research, attend seminars, and network within the AI community. You will NOT be working or being compensated for any of your activities (see below for stipend details).

![ðŸ›« Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

You plan to depart the U.S. at the conclusion of the program or soon thereafter. You have strong ties to your home country and plan to return once the program is over.

## Travel Insurance

If you do not have health insurance in the US, we recommend purchasing travel insurance. Check with your current health insurance provider to find out whether you are already covered in the US. Without insurance, healthcare in the US is extremely expensive: the [average cost](https://www.talktomira.com/post/how-much-does-an-er-visit-cost#) of an emergency room visit in California is almost $3000. Make sure you purchase insurance that extends for the duration of your trip and covers care in California.

Is there a slack channel for announcing papers Iâ€™d like to discuss with others? Or announce that Iâ€™d like a study group with available participants?

We have a couple of Slack channels for specific topics like #interpretability. If youâ€™re starting a reading group, you can create a channel and announce it in #general for people to join. If you want to schedule a one-off meeting to discuss a specific paper, feel free to use #scheduling .

What if I uncover an info-hazard?

If you or your mentor believe that your project would contain [infohazards](https://www.lesswrong.com/tag/information-hazards), please let us know, and we will discuss options. If you have any questions, feel free to send Jonathan a message on Slack, or ask anonymously ( [this form](https://www.matsprogram.org/contact) goes directly to Ryan and Christian).

I have a concern about whether some work Iâ€™m doing, or someone I know is doing, might be dangerous. What should I do/who should I talk to? (I donâ€™t want to get them in trouble, but I also care about preventing bad things.)

Definitely bring it up with your research manager and potentially Ryan! You can also ask your mentor for a second opinion if you think something is dangerous, or [report it anonymously](https://airtable.com/appZq2f1sM0tW9kH7/pagP5z64n6Eh6MEMM/form). The CM is available to talk to as well.

If I want to demo something, how do I announce this?

Your cohort channel in Slack works, though we may add a specialized channel for this later if thereâ€™s demand.

I have a technical issue getting something working on my laptop and Iâ€™m blocked. Who can help?

Your Research Manager is the best point person to help debug technical issues if youâ€™re stuck.

Who owns intellectual property produced at MATS?

MATS will not be involved in conversations around intellectual property (IP). Mentors and fellows should discuss IP considerations and ownership within the first few weeks of the program. If you are unsure about your employerâ€™s or institutionâ€™s IP policy for content created at MATS, we suggest reading your employment agreement or consulting your organizationâ€™s legal counsel. If you have questions about IP or need assistance mediating agreements with your fellows, please reach out to Christian on Slack or by email at christian@matsprogram.org.

Can I list MATS as an affiliation when publishing a paper (on Arxiv, at NeurIPS, etc)?

Yes!

### Funding/finances

What happens to my grant if I do a few weeks of the program and then drop out early?

AI Safety Support calculated the grant amounts based on a per-hour time valuation of 40 hours per week over the course of the full 12 weeks. If you drop out of the program early or participate part-time, they will modify the grant amount accordingly. Please let your Research Manager know as soon as possible if you intend to reduce your involvement in the MATS Program.

Where do I send reimbursement requests?

Fill out the correct form on the reimbursements page.

Do I have to pay taxes on the grant I received for the MATS Program?

MATS participants may have to pay taxes on their grants based on the rules of the countries where they are a resident for tax purposes. The grants should be regarded as "private grants from a non-profit entity (i.e., [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not MATS) provided to individuals for independent research and participation in a US-based seminar program." While fellow grants are provided by [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not [Effective Ventures](https://ev.org/), fellows may find [this tax advice](https://funds.effectivealtruism.org/help/1lZgor0q3CImJwTt0xefPR) helpful.

Who do I talk to about taxes?

While fellow grants are provided by [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not [Effective Ventures](https://ev.org/), fellows may find [this tax advice](https://funds.effectivealtruism.org/help/1lZgor0q3CImJwTt0xefPR) helpful.

We recommend fellows consult a tax accountant if necessary.

When do I get grant payments? Am I paid all at once? Can I receive partial payment early to cover costs for food, etc?

**Quotes from the handbook:**

# MATS Winter â€˜26 Fellow Handbook

![ðŸ‘‹ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

Welcome to the MATS Winter 2026 cohort! This handbook is your one-stop-shop for all your program-related questions and needs.

![ðŸ”‘ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

Door code for Lighthaven: 4517

![ðŸ“Ž Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

Here are some handy links:
â€” [MATS Website](https://www.matsprogram.org/)
â€” [Winter Retrospective](https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/Z87fSrxQb4yLXKcTk/mats-winter-2023-24-retrospective) and [Talent Needs Report](https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/QzQQvGJYDeaDE4Cfg/talent-needs-in-technical-ai-safety)
â€” Orientation Slides (coming soon!)
â€” [Air-gapped Community Health Form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdGaA1qRLnoJLNqlMJPFtTtkxYzuc7o_NE5wSJQ1JQMVEr7DQ/viewform?usp=sf_link)
â€” [Ops Request Form](https://airtable.com/appZq2f1sM0tW9kH7/pagQXSzPyPRWV8H0H/form) (matsprogram.org/req)
â€” [Compute Request](https://forms.matsprogram.org/compute-request)
â€” [Guest Form](https://airtable.com/appZq2f1sM0tW9kH7/pagRDl1p3SzDhh25S/form) (for your personal guests to Lighthaven during working hours)
â€” [Office EoI](https://airtable.com/appZq2f1sM0tW9kH7/pagvVP821ZgDug1nI/form) (for people in the broader community who might want to visit)

## Program Requirements and Key Dates

Jan 5 - March 28: Research Phase (12 weeks)

Jan 5: Orientation Day

Jan 7: Alumni Lightning Talks

Jan 9: Kick-off Mixer with wider Bay Area AIS community: [RSVP](https://luma.com/ayrz6pxc)

Jan 9: Housing and office agreements due to Nate

Feb 6: Milestone #1 Research project description is due

TBD: Career Fair

March (TBD): Symposium abstract/slides due

March 28: Milestone #2 Fellow Symposium presentations and poster session

March 29 by 2 PM: Check out of MATS-provided accommodations (unless specifically told otherwise)

April 11: Extension Phase begins (for select fellows)

![](https://matsprogram.notion.site/image/attachment%3A351031c9-064d-4f85-aef8-dadb8b928844%3AScreenshot_2025-12-15_at_2.23.20_PM.png?table=block&id=2dfa0e14-b0ad-802f-9fac-de21b926c958&spaceId=0d3e27ad-4523-4665-9d59-8502d77dc404&width=2000&userId=&cache=v2)

## Financial Support

MATS itself cannot provide any funding; however, [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) has generously offered to provide a grant totaling $15k for completing the Research Phase. This will be disbursed in two parts: half at the beginning and half at the end of the main MATS program. The second half of the grant is prorated based on the number of weeks fellows participate in the program.

MATS participants may have to pay taxes on their grants based on the rules of the countries where they are a resident for tax purposes. The grants should be regarded as "private grants from a non-profit entity (i.e., [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not MATS) provided to individuals for independent research and participation in a US-based seminar program." While fellow grants are provided by [AI Safety Support](https://www.aisafetysupport.org/) and not [Effective Ventures](https://ev.org/), fellows may find [this tax advice](https://funds.effectivealtruism.org/help/1lZgor0q3CImJwTt0xefPR) helpful.

## Training Materials

### Mentor Curriculum

Some mentors have developed a training curriculum for their fellows. Fellows are expected to carefully read through their mentorâ€™s assigned curriculum and explore any disagreements or confusion in their weekly mentor meetings. If you have already thoroughly read any mentor curriculum elements prior to the start of the program, or find that you are progressing faster than expected, please reach out to your mentor for more advanced reading material.

## Research Phase Overview (Jan 5 - March 28)

### Commitment

The default time frame for this program phase is 40hrs/week during Jan 5 - March 28, but these dates are flexible. For example, some fellows may choose to do part-time for some weeks to accommodate school commitments. Please contact a member of the MATS team or email exec@matsprogram.org if you would like alternative program dates or weekly commitments.

By default, we expect fellows to complete this program in-person in our Berkeley, California offices, with some exceptions of fellows who will complete the program from London, UK. Accommodation will also be provided in Berkeley; housing will be co-located with the office for convenience. We will also try to tailor accommodations to your preferences, e.g., for greater work-home separation. Please contact a member of the MATS team or email kali@matsprogram.org if you require any support.

### Milestones

#### \#1: Research project description (due Feb 6)

The ~2 page project description consists of a description of your proposed research project during the MATS program and a justification of why you chose this project in consultation with your mentor. The RP is intended to encourage fellows to critically evaluate their projectâ€™s theory of change and provide the MATS team and MATS grant manager with data on the program.

More information will be released about the project description in the coming weeks.

#### \#2: Fellow Symposium (March 28)

The Research Phase concludes with a full-day Symposium, during which all fellows present posters about their research project and some teams deliver 10-minute talks to their peers and members of the Berkeley AI safety community.

You can find more information about the assignment, along with the rubric and and submission form on the Symposium section of the Fellow Handbook.

### Research Projects

During the research phase of the program, mentors will meet with fellows for around 1-2 h/week to share their research agenda and supervise the fellowsâ€™ research projects. Fellows' research directions may initially be chosen by the mentors, but by default, fellows are expected to develop their independent research direction as the program continues.

![ðŸ‘‹ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

Meta has restricted LLaMa usage to organizations with fewer than 700 million monthly active users, prohibiting use by the following organizations: Alphabet, Tencent, TikTok, Microsoft, Snap, and Telegram. Because Google DeepMind is owned by Alphabet, fellows working with DeepMind mentors are encouraged to check in with them about this. If you anticipate this will be disruptive to your work at MATS, please reach out to Ryan via Slack.

![ðŸ–Šï¸ Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

MATS does not handle IP discussions; mentors and fellows should discuss IP ownership in the first few weeks. Consult Christian for help at christian@matsprogram.org.

### Posting on LessWrong

content.text:
Base directory for this skill: /Users/yoav/.claude/plugins/cache/claude-plugins-official/plugin-dev/b97f6eadd929/skills/skill-development

# Skill Development for Claude Code Plugins

This skill provides guidance for creating effective skills for Claude Code plugins.

## About Skills

Skills are modular, self-contained packages that extend Claude's capabilities by providing
specialized knowledge, workflows, and tools. Think of them as "onboarding guides" for specific
domains or tasksâ€”they transform Claude from a general-purpose agent into a specialized agent
equipped with procedural knowledge that no model can fully possess.

### What Skills Provide

1. Specialized workflows - Multi-step procedures for specific domains
2. Tool integrations - Instructions for working with specific file formats or APIs
3. Domain expertise - Company-specific knowledge, schemas, business logic
4. Bundled resources - Scripts, references, and assets for complex and repetitive tasks

### Anatomy of a Skill

Every skill consists of a required SKILL.md file and optional bundled resources:

```
skill-name/
â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md (required)
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ YAML frontmatter metadata (required)
â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ name: (required)
â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ description: (required)
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Markdown instructions (required)
â””â”€â”€ Bundled Resources (optional)
    â”œâ”€â”€ scripts/          - Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.)
    â”œâ”€â”€ references/       - Documentation intended to be loaded into context as needed
    â””â”€â”€ assets/           - Files used in output (templates, icons, fonts, etc.)
```

#### SKILL.md (required)

**Metadata Quality:** The `name` and `description` in YAML frontmatter determine when Claude will use the skill. Be specific about what the skill does and when to use it. Use the third-person (e.g. "This skill should be used when..." instead of "Use this skill when...").

#### Bundled Resources (optional)

##### Scripts (`scripts/`)

Executable code (Python/Bash/etc.) for tasks that require deterministic reliability or are repeatedly rewritten.

- **When to include**: When the same code is being rewritten repeatedly or deterministic reliability is needed
- **Example**: `scripts/rotate_pdf.py` for PDF rotation tasks
- **Benefits**: Token efficient, deterministic, may be executed without loading into context
- **Note**: Scripts may still need to be read by Claude for patching or environment-specific adjustments

##### References (`references/`)

Documentation and reference material intended to be loaded as needed into context to inform Claude's process and thinking.

- **When to include**: For documentation that Claude should reference while working
- **Examples**: `references/finance.md` for financial schemas, `references/mnda.md` for company NDA template, `references/policies.md` for company policies, `references/api_docs.md` for API specifications
- **Use cases**: Database schemas, API documentation, domain knowledge, company policies, detailed workflow guides
- **Benefits**: Keeps SKILL.md lean, loaded only when Claude determines it's needed
- **Best practice**: If files are large (>10k words), include grep search patterns in SKILL.md
- **Avoid duplication**: Information should live in either SKILL.md or references files, not both. Prefer references files for detailed information unless it's truly core to the skillâ€”this keeps SKILL.md lean while making information discoverable without hogging the context window. Keep only essential procedural instructions and workflow guidance in SKILL.md; move detailed reference material, schemas, and examples to references files.

##### Assets (`assets/`)

Files not intended to be loaded into context, but rather used within the output Claude produces.

- **When to include**: When the skill needs files that will be used in the final output
- **Examples**: `assets/logo.png` for brand assets, `assets/slides.pptx` for PowerPoint templates, `assets/frontend-template/` for HTML/React boilerplate, `assets/font.ttf` for typography
- **Use cases**: Templates, images, icons, boilerplate code, fonts, sample documents that get copied or modified
- **Benefits**: Separates output resources from documentation, enables Claude to use files without loading them into context

### Progressive Disclosure Design Principle

Skills use a three-level loading system to manage context efficiently:

1. **Metadata (name + description)** - Always in context (~100 words)
2. **SKILL.md body** - When skill triggers (<5k words)
3. **Bundled resources** - As needed by Claude (Unlimited*)

*Unlimited because scripts can be executed without reading into context window.

## Skill Creation Process

To create a skill, follow the "Skill Creation Process" in order, skipping steps only if there is a clear reason why they are not applicable.

### Step 1: Understanding the Skill with Concrete Examples

Skip this step only when the skill's usage patterns are already clearly understood. It remains valuable even when working with an existing skill.

To create an effective skill, clearly understand concrete examples of how the skill will be used. This understanding can come from either direct user examples or generated examples that are validated with user feedback.

For example, when building an image-editor skill, relevant questions include:

- "What functionality should the image-editor skill support? Editing, rotating, anything else?"
- "Can you give some examples of how this skill would be used?"
- "I can imagine users asking for things like 'Remove the red-eye from this image' or 'Rotate this image'. Are there other ways you imagine this skill being used?"
- "What would a user say that should trigger this skill?"

To avoid overwhelming users, avoid asking too many questions in a single message. Start with the most important questions and follow up as needed for better effectiveness.

Conclude this step when there is a clear sense of the functionality the skill should support.

### Step 2: Planning the Reusable Skill Contents

To turn concrete examples into an effective skill, analyze each example by:

1. Considering how to execute on the example from scratch
2. Identifying what scripts, references, and assets would be helpful when executing these workflows repeatedly

Example: When building a `pdf-editor` skill to handle queries like "Help me rotate this PDF," the analysis shows:

1. Rotating a PDF requires re-writing the same code each time
2. A `scripts/rotate_pdf.py` script would be helpful to store in the skill

Example: When designing a `frontend-webapp-builder` skill for queries like "Build me a todo app" or "Build me a dashboard to track my steps," the analysis shows:

1. Writing a frontend webapp requires the same boilerplate HTML/React each time
2. An `assets/hello-world/` template containing the boilerplate HTML/React project files would be helpful to store in the skill

Example: When building a `big-query` skill to handle queries like "How many users have logged in today?" the analysis shows:

1. Querying BigQuery requires re-discovering the table schemas and relationships each time
2. A `references/schema.md` file documenting the table schemas would be helpful to store in the skill

**For Claude Code plugins:** When building a hooks skill, the analysis shows:
1. Developers repeatedly need to validate hooks.json and test hook scripts
2. `scripts/validate-hook-schema.sh` and `scripts/test-hook.sh` utilities would be helpful
3. `references/patterns.md` for detailed hook patterns to avoid bloating SKILL.md

To establish the skill's contents, analyze each concrete example to create a list of the reusable resources to include: scripts, references, and assets.

### Step 3: Create Skill Structure

For Claude Code plugins, create the skill directory structure:

```bash
mkdir -p plugin-name/skills/skill-name/{references,examples,scripts}
touch plugin-name/skills/skill-name/SKILL.md
```

**Note:** Unlike the generic skill-creator which uses `init_skill.py`, plugin skills are created directly in the plugin's `skills/` directory with a simpler manual structure.

### Step 4: Edit the Skill

When editing the (newly-created or existing) skill, remember that the skill is being created for another instance of Claude to use. Focus on including information that would be beneficial and non-obvious to Claude. Consider what procedural knowledge, domain-specific details, or reusable assets would help another Claude instance execute these tasks more effectively.

#### Start with Reusable Skill Contents

To begin implementation, start with the reusable resources identified above: `scripts/`, `references/`, and `assets/` files. Note that this step may require user input. For example, when implementing a `brand-guidelines` skill, the user may need to provide brand assets or templates to store in `assets/`, or documentation to store in `references/`.

Also, delete any example files and directories not needed for the skill. Create only the directories you actually need (references/, examples/, scripts/).

#### Update SKILL.md

**Writing Style:** Write the entire skill using **imperative/infinitive form** (verb-first instructions), not second person. Use objective, instructional language (e.g., "To accomplish X, do Y" rather than "You should do X" or "If you need to do X"). This maintains consistency and clarity for AI consumption.

**Description (Frontmatter):** Use third-person format with specific trigger phrases:

```yaml
---
name: Skill Name
description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "specific phrase 1", "specific phrase 2", "specific phrase 3". Include exact phrases users would say that should trigger this skill. Be concrete and specific.
version: 0.1.0
---
```

**Good description examples:**
```yaml
description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook", "validate tool use", "implement prompt-based hooks", or mentions hook events (PreToolUse, PostToolUse, Stop).
```

**Bad description examples:**
```yaml
description: Use this skill when working with hooks.  # Wrong person, vague
description: Load when user needs hook help.  # Not third person
description: Provides hook guidance.  # No trigger phrases
```

To complete SKILL.md body, answer the following questions:

1. What is the purpose of the skill, in a few sentences?
2. When should the skill be used? (Include this in frontmatter description with specific triggers)
3. In practice, how should Claude use the skill? All reusable skill contents developed above should be referenced so that Claude knows how to use them.

**Keep SKILL.md lean:** Target 1,500-2,000 words for the body. Move detailed content to references/:
- Detailed patterns â†’ `references/patterns.md`
- Advanced techniques â†’ `references/advanced.md`
- Migration guides â†’ `references/migration.md`
- API references â†’ `references/api-reference.md`

**Reference resources in SKILL.md:**
```markdown
## Additional Resources

### Reference Files

For detailed patterns and techniques, consult:
- **`references/patterns.md`** - Common patterns
- **`references/advanced.md`** - Advanced use cases

### Example Files

Working examples in `examples/`:
- **`example-script.sh`** - Working example
```

### Step 5: Validate and Test

**For plugin skills, validation is different from generic skills:**

1. **Check structure**: Skill directory in `plugin-name/skills/skill-name/`
2. **Validate SKILL.md**: Has frontmatter with name and description
3. **Check trigger phrases**: Description includes specific user queries
4. **Verify writing style**: Body uses imperative/infinitive form, not second person
5. **Test progressive disclosure**: SKILL.md is lean (~1,500-2,000 words), detailed content in references/
6. **Check references**: All referenced files exist
7. **Validate examples**: Examples are complete and correct
8. **Test scripts**: Scripts are executable and work correctly

**Use the skill-reviewer agent:**
```
Ask: "Review my skill and check if it follows best practices"
```

The skill-reviewer agent will check description quality, content organization, and progressive disclosure.

### Step 6: Iterate

After testing the skill, users may request improvements. Often this happens right after using the skill, with fresh context of how the skill performed.

**Iteration workflow:**
1. Use the skill on real tasks
2. Notice struggles or inefficiencies
3. Identify how SKILL.md or bundled resources should be updated
4. Implement changes and test again

**Common improvements:**
- Strengthen trigger phrases in description
- Move long sections from SKILL.md to references/
- Add missing examples or scripts
- Clarify ambiguous instructions
- Add edge case handling

## Plugin-Specific Considerations

### Skill Location in Plugins

Plugin skills live in the plugin's `skills/` directory:

```
my-plugin/
â”œâ”€â”€ .claude-plugin/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ plugin.json
â”œâ”€â”€ commands/
â”œâ”€â”€ agents/
â””â”€â”€ skills/
    â””â”€â”€ my-skill/
        â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md
        â”œâ”€â”€ references/
        â”œâ”€â”€ examples/
        â””â”€â”€ scripts/
```

### Auto-Discovery

Claude Code automatically discovers skills:
- Scans `skills/` directory
- Finds subdirectories containing `SKILL.md`
- Loads skill metadata (name + description) always
- Loads SKILL.md body when skill triggers
- Loads references/examples when needed

### No Packaging Needed

Plugin skills are distributed as part of the plugin, not as separate ZIP files. Users get skills when they install the plugin.

### Testing in Plugins

Test skills by installing plugin locally:

```bash
# Test with --plugin-dir
cc --plugin-dir /path/to/plugin

# Ask questions that should trigger the skill
# Verify skill loads correctly
```

## Examples from Plugin-Dev

Study the skills in this plugin as examples of best practices:

**hook-development skill:**
- Excellent trigger phrases: "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook", etc.
- Lean SKILL.md (1,651 words)
- 3 references/ files for detailed content
- 3 examples/ of working hooks
- 3 scripts/ utilities

**agent-development skill:**
- Strong triggers: "create an agent", "agent frontmatter", etc.
- Focused SKILL.md (1,438 words)
- References include the AI generation prompt from Claude Code
- Complete agent examples

**plugin-settings skill:**
- Specific triggers: "plugin settings", ".local.md files", "YAML frontmatter"
- References show real implementations (multi-agent-swarm, ralph-loop)
- Working parsing scripts

Each demonstrates progressive disclosure and strong triggering.

## Progressive Disclosure in Practice

### What Goes in SKILL.md

**Include (always loaded when skill triggers):**
- Core concepts and overview
- Essential procedures and workflows
- Quick reference tables
- Pointers to references/examples/scripts
- Most common use cases

**Keep under 3,000 words, ideally 1,500-2,000 words**

### What Goes in references/

**Move to references/ (loaded as needed):**
- Detailed patterns and advanced techniques
- Comprehensive API documentation
- Migration guides
- Edge cases and troubleshooting
- Extensive examples and walkthroughs

**Each reference file can be large (2,000-5,000+ words)**

### What Goes in examples/

**Working code examples:**
- Complete, runnable scripts
- Configuration files
- Template files
- Real-world usage examples

**Users can copy and adapt these directly**

### What Goes in scripts/

**Utility scripts:**
- Validation tools
- Testing helpers
- Parsing utilities
- Automation scripts

**Should be executable and documented**

## Writing Style Requirements

### Imperative/Infinitive Form

Write using verb-first instructions, not second person:

**Correct (imperative):**
```
To create a hook, define the event type.
Configure the MCP server with authentication.
Validate settings before use.
```

**Incorrect (second person):**
```
You should create a hook by defining the event type.
You need to configure the MCP server.
You must validate settings before use.
```

### Third-Person in Description

The frontmatter description must use third person:

**Correct:**
```yaml
description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create X", "configure Y"...
```

**Incorrect:**
```yaml
description: Use this skill when you want to create X...
description: Load this skill when user asks...
```

### Objective, Instructional Language

Focus on what to do, not who should do it:

**Correct:**
```
Parse the frontmatter using sed.
Extract fields with grep.
Validate values before use.
```

**Incorrect:**
```
You can parse the frontmatter...
Claude should extract fields...
The user might validate values...
```

## Validation Checklist

Before finalizing a skill:

**Structure:**
- [ ] SKILL.md file exists with valid YAML frontmatter
- [ ] Frontmatter has `name` and `description` fields
- [ ] Markdown body is present and substantial
- [ ] Referenced files actually exist

**Description Quality:**
- [ ] Uses third person ("This skill should be used when...")
- [ ] Includes specific trigger phrases users would say
- [ ] Lists concrete scenarios ("create X", "configure Y")
- [ ] Not vague or generic

**Content Quality:**
- [ ] SKILL.md body uses imperative/infinitive form
- [ ] Body is focused and lean (1,500-2,000 words ideal, <5k max)
- [ ] Detailed content moved to references/
- [ ] Examples are complete and working
- [ ] Scripts are executable and documented

**Progressive Disclosure:**
- [ ] Core concepts in SKILL.md
- [ ] Detailed docs in references/
- [ ] Working code in examples/
- [ ] Utilities in scripts/
- [ ] SKILL.md references these resources

**Testing:**
- [ ] Skill triggers on expected user queries
- [ ] Content is helpful for intended tasks
- [ ] No duplicated information across files
- [ ] References load when needed

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: Weak Trigger Description

âŒ **Bad:**
```yaml
description: Provides guidance for working with hooks.
```

**Why bad:** Vague, no specific trigger phrases, not third person

âœ… **Good:**
```yaml
description: This skill should be used when the user asks to "create a hook", "add a PreToolUse hook", "validate tool use", or mentions hook events. Provides comprehensive hooks API guidance.
```

**Why good:** Third person, specific phrases, concrete scenarios

### Mistake 2: Too Much in SKILL.md

âŒ **Bad:**
```
skill-name/
â””â”€â”€ SKILL.md  (8,000 words - everything in one file)
```

**Why bad:** Bloats context when skill loads, detailed content always loaded

âœ… **Good:**
```
skill-name/
â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md  (1,800 words - core essentials)
â””â”€â”€ references/
    â”œâ”€â”€ patterns.md (2,500 words)
    â””â”€â”€ advanced.md (3,700 words)
```

**Why good:** Progressive disclosure, detailed content loaded only when needed

### Mistake 3: Second Person Writing

âŒ **Bad:**
```markdown
You should start by reading the configuration file.
You need to validate the input.
You can use the grep tool to search.
```

**Why bad:** Second person, not imperative form

âœ… **Good:**
```markdown
Start by reading the configuration file.
Validate the input before processing.
Use the grep tool to search for patterns.
```

**Why good:** Imperative form, direct instructions

### Mistake 4: Missing Resource References

âŒ **Bad:**
```markdown
# SKILL.md

[Core content]

[No mention of references/ or examples/]
```

**Why bad:** Claude doesn't know references exist

âœ… **Good:**
```markdown
# SKILL.md

[Core content]

## Additional Resources

### Reference Files
- **`references/patterns.md`** - Detailed patterns
- **`references/advanced.md`** - Advanced techniques

### Examples
- **`examples/script.sh`** - Working example
```

**Why good:** Claude knows where to find additional information

## Quick Reference

### Minimal Skill

```
skill-name/
â””â”€â”€ SKILL.md
```

Good for: Simple knowledge, no complex resources needed

### Standard Skill (Recommended)

```
skill-name/
â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md
â”œâ”€â”€ references/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ detailed-guide.md
â””â”€â”€ examples/
    â””â”€â”€ working-example.sh
```

Good for: Most plugin skills with detailed documentation

### Complete Skill

```
skill-name/
â”œâ”€â”€ SKILL.md
â”œâ”€â”€ references/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ patterns.md
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ advanced.md
â”œâ”€â”€ examples/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ example1.sh
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ example2.json
â””â”€â”€ scripts/
    â””â”€â”€ validate.sh
```

Good for: Complex domains with validation utilities

## Best Practices Summary

âœ… **DO:**
- Use third-person in description ("This skill should be used when...")
- Include specific trigger phrases ("create X", "configure Y")
- Keep SKILL.md lean (1,500-2,000 words)
- Use progressive disclosure (move details to references/)
- Write in imperative/infinitive form
- Reference supporting files clearly
- Provide working examples
- Create utility scripts for common operations
- Study plugin-dev's skills as templates

âŒ **DON'T:**
- Use second person anywhere
- Have vague trigger conditions
- Put everything in SKILL.md (>3,000 words without references/)
- Write in second person ("You should...")
- Leave resources unreferenced
- Include broken or incomplete examples
- Skip validation

## Additional Resources

### Study These Skills

Plugin-dev's skills demonstrate best practices:
- `../hook-development/` - Progressive disclosure, utilities
- `../agent-development/` - AI-assisted creation, references
- `../mcp-integration/` - Comprehensive references
- `../plugin-settings/` - Real-world examples
- `../command-development/` - Clear critical concepts
- `../plugin-structure/` - Good organization

### Reference Files

For complete skill-creator methodology:
- **`references/skill-creator-original.md`** - Full original skill-creator content

## Implementation Workflow

To create a skill for your plugin:

1. **Understand use cases**: Identify concrete examples of skill usage
2. **Plan resources**: Determine what scripts/references/examples needed
3. **Create structure**: `mkdir -p skills/skill-name/{references,examples,scripts}`
4. **Write SKILL.md**:
   - Frontmatter with third-person description and trigger phrases
   - Lean body (1,500-2,000 words) in imperative form
   - Reference supporting files
5. **Add resources**: Create references/, examples/, scripts/ as needed
6. **Validate**: Check description, writing style, organization
7. **Test**: Verify skill loads on expected triggers
8. **Iterate**: Improve based on usage

Focus on strong trigger descriptions, progressive disclosure, and imperative writing style for effective skills that load when needed and provide targeted guidance.

## Workflow

### Step 1: Fetch the Handbook

**Important:** Use curl via Bash, not the built-in Fetch tool. The Fetch tool summarizes content, but the full handbook is needed for accurate quotes.

```bash
curl -s "https://firecrawl.alignment-hive.com/api/notion?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmatsprogram.notion.site%2Fmats-winter-26-fellow-handbook"
```

### Step 2: Find Relevant Information

Read the curl output and locate sections relevant to the user's question. Extract direct quotes from the handbook.

**Recursive fetching:** If the handbook links to other Notion pages with additional details (e.g., Compute Docs, Community Health Policy), fetch those linked pages using the same API pattern:

```bash
curl -s "https://firecrawl.alignment-hive.com/api/notion?url=<url-encoded-notion-link>"
```

Follow linked Notion pages when the main handbook doesn't contain enough detail to answer the user's question.
